title: W07.1 - U3 (Week B) - Class Code
text:
Introduction to the functions you will be learning in this unit. Below is the code used in the video so you can follow along.

# %%
import pandas as pd 
import numpy as np
import plotly.express as px
import sqlite3


# %%
# Upgrade pip if needed
import sys
!{sys.executable} -m pip install --upgrade pip

Requirement already satisfied: pip in c:\users\drewl\appdata\local\programs\python\python312\lib\site-packages (24.0)



# %%
# careful to list your path to the file. Or save this code in the same folder as the sqlite file.
sqlite_file = 'lahmansbaseballdb.sqlite'
con = sqlite3.connect(sqlite_file)


# %%
q = '''SELECT cp.playerID, schoolID, salary, cp.yearID, teamID 
        FROM salaries s join collegeplaying cp on cp.playerID = s.playerID 
        Where schoolID = 'idbyuid'
        Order by s.salary desc'''
batting5 = pd.read_sql_query(q,con)
batting5

# %%

q = '''

SELECT playerID, yearID, CAST(AB AS FLOAT), CAST(H AS FLOAT), CAST(H AS FLOAT)/ CAST(AB AS FLOAT) as battingAverage
FROM batting
WHERE AB >= 1
ORDER BY battingAverage desc, playerID
LIMIT 5

'''

battingAverage = pd.read_sql_query(q,con)
battingAverage

# What columns do we want to select?
q = '''

SELECT playerID, yearID, CAST(AB AS FLOAT), CAST(H AS FLOAT), CAST(H AS FLOAT)/ CAST(AB AS FLOAT) as battingAverage
FROM batting
WHERE AB >= 10
ORDER BY battingAverage desc, playerID
LIMIT 5

'''

battingAverage = pd.read_sql_query(q,con)
battingAverage

# %%
# What calculation do we want to perform?

q = '''

SELECT playerID, yearID, CAST(AB AS FLOAT), CAST(H AS FLOAT), SUM(CAST(H AS FLOAT))/ SUM(CAST(AB AS FLOAT)) as battingAverage
FROM batting
WHERE AB >= 100
ORDER BY battingAverage desc, playerID
LIMIT 5

'''

battingAverage = pd.read_sql_query(q,con)
battingAverage








playerID
yearID
CAST(AB AS FLOAT)
CAST(H AS FLOAT)
battingAverage

# %%
# What name do we give our calculated column?

q = '''
SELECT teamid, 
        Sum(r) as Total_Runs
FROM batting
GROUP BY teamid
LIMIT 10000
'''

batting_calc = pd.read_sql_query(q,con)
batting_calc

fig = px.bar(batting_calc[(batting_calc.teamID == 'BR1') | (batting_calc.teamID == 'BRF')], x='teamID', y='Total_Runs', title='Total Runs by Team')
fig.show()

title: about me
text: In this project, I will be looking at the data from the Bureau of Transportation Statistics to see which airports have the least amount of days at which times of the year and other interesting finds within the data!

title: about me
text: In this project, I will be looking at the data from the Bureau of Transportation Statistics to see which airports have the least amount of days at which times of the year and other interesting finds within the data!

title: about me
text:
Loading in The JSON Data

df = pd.read_json("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byuidatascience/data4missing/master/data-raw/flights_missing/flights_missing.json")

# x = json.load(f)

# f.close()

# df = pd.DataFrame(x)

title: about me
section: Clean Up - Clean Up Everybody Do Your Share
text:
Clean Up - Clean Up Everybody Do Your Share
Fix all of the varied missing data types in the data to be consistent

# loop through tasks in my tasks list and sort the data by airport to find the mean of certain delays and fill the nan values with their respective mean.

tasks = ["minutes_delayed_carrier", "minutes_delayed_nas"]

means = df.groupby("airport_code")["minutes_delayed_carrier"].mean().to_dict()

for task in tasks:
  for airport in means:
    mean_delay = df[df["airport_code"] == airport][task].fillna(means[airport])

    df.loc[df["airport_code"] == airport, task] = mean_delay


# This is a quick fix to the nan values in year, but does not take into account if january is a nan value and we forward fill from last year

df.year.ffill(inplace=True)

include figures in chunks and discuss your findings in the figure.

# This is a quick fix to the nan values in year, but does not take into account if january is a nan value and we forward fill from last year

df = df[df['month'] != 'n/a']

df['month'] = df['month'].replace('Febuary', 'February')

title: about me
text:
Delays
Which airport has the worst delays?
From the looks of the graph below, ORD airport has the worst delays over the course of 10 years. This shows that if your looking to take a trip, for a vacation, or on short-term notice, well… Let’s hope you don’t live where that airport is!
::: {#cell-chart stuff .cell execution_count=6}
chart = px.bar(df,
    x="airport_code", 
    y="minutes_delayed_total",
    title="Total Minutes in Delays",
)
chart.show()

                                                
My uselful chart

:::

title: about me
text:
Best Time to Travel
What is the best month to fly if you want to avoid delays of any length?
It seems to be that November would be the best month to travel because across all the airports, that month has the least delayed time.

grph = px.bar(df,
x="month",
y="minutes_delayed_total",
color="airport_code",
title = "Best Month to Travel"
)
grph.show()

title: about me
text:
Weather
create a new column that calculates the total number of flights delayed by weather (both severe and mild)

df["weather_delays"] = df.num_of_flights_total + (df.num_of_delays_late_aircraft * .3) + np.where(df['month'].isin(['April','May','June','July','August']), (df.num_of_delays_nas * .4), (df.num_of_delays_nas * .65))

title: about me
text:
Weather Delays Compared to Airports
Using the new weather variable calculated above, create a barplot showing the proportion of all flights that are delayed by weather at each airport
It looks like Atlanta, Georgia experiences the most weather delays than any other airport.

charts = px.bar(df, x="airport_code", y="weather_delays", title="Delays vs Airports")

charts.show()

                                                
Chart!

title: Client Report - Late flights and missing data (JSON files)
text: In this project, I will be looking at the data from the Bureau of Transportation Statistics to see which airports have the least amount of days at which times of the year and other interesting finds within the data!

title: Client Report - Late flights and missing data (JSON files)
text: In this project, I will be looking at the data from the Bureau of Transportation Statistics to see which airports have the least amount of days at which times of the year and other interesting finds within the data!

title: Client Report - Late flights and missing data (JSON files)
text:
Loading in The JSON Data


Loading the json data and turning it into a dataframe
df = pd.read_json("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byuidatascience/data4missing/master/data-raw/flights_missing/flights_missing.json")

# x = json.load(f)

# f.close()

# df = pd.DataFrame(x)

title: Client Report - Late flights and missing data (JSON files)
section: Clean Up - Clean Up Everybody Do Your Share
text:
Clean Up - Clean Up Everybody Do Your Share
Fix all of the varied missing data types in the data to be consistent


Cleaning up data and filling NAs
# loop through tasks in my tasks list and sort the data by airport to find the mean of certain delays and fill the nan values with their respective mean.

tasks = ["minutes_delayed_carrier", "minutes_delayed_nas"]

means = df.groupby("airport_code")["minutes_delayed_carrier"].mean().to_dict()

for task in tasks:
  for airport in means:
    mean_delay = df[df["airport_code"] == airport][task].fillna(means[airport])

    df.loc[df["airport_code"] == airport, task] = mean_delay




Show the code
# This is a quick fix to the nan values in year, but does not take into account if january is a nan value and we forward fill from last year

df.year.ffill(inplace=True)


include figures in chunks and discuss your findings in the figure.


Show the code
# This is a quick fix to the nan values in year, but does not take into account if january is a nan value and we forward fill from last year

df = df[df['month'] != 'n/a']

df['month'] = df['month'].replace('Febuary', 'February')

title: Client Report - Late flights and missing data (JSON files)
text:
Delays
Which airport has the worst delays?
From the looks of the graph below, ORD airport has the worst delays over the course of 10 years. This shows that if your looking to take a trip, for a vacation, or on short-term notice, well… Let’s hope you don’t live where that airport is!
::: {#cell-chart stuff .cell execution_count=6}

plot example
chart = px.bar(df,
    x="airport_code", 
    y="minutes_delayed_total",
    title="Total Minutes in Delays",
)
chart.show()


                                                
My uselful chart

:::

title: Client Report - Late flights and missing data (JSON files)
text:
Best Time to Travel
What is the best month to fly if you want to avoid delays of any length?
It seems to be that November would be the best month to travel because across all the airports, that month has the least delayed time.


table example
grph = px.bar(df,
x="month",
y="minutes_delayed_total",
color="airport_code",
title = "Best Month to Travel"
)
grph.show()

title: Client Report - Late flights and missing data (JSON files)
text:
Weather
create a new column that calculates the total number of flights delayed by weather (both severe and mild)


Read and format data
df["weather_delays"] = df.num_of_flights_total + (df.num_of_delays_late_aircraft * .3) + np.where(df['month'].isin(['April','May','June','July','August']), (df.num_of_delays_nas * .4), (df.num_of_delays_nas * .65))

title: Client Report - Late flights and missing data (JSON files)
text:
Weather Delays Compared to Airports
Using the new weather variable calculated above, create a barplot showing the proportion of all flights that are delayed by weather at each airport
It looks like Atlanta, Georgia experiences the most weather delays than any other airport.


plot example
charts = px.bar(df, x="airport_code", y="weather_delays", title="Delays vs Airports")

charts.show()


                                                
Chart!
